nexttext:
\noindent 
References~\cite{G-K-11,GL} obtain the following relations for unpolarized structure functions:
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex1.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle 2\pi\frac{d^{2}\sigma(\gamma^{*}p\to p\pi^{0})}{dtd\phi_{\pi}}" display="inline"><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>π</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mrow><msup><mi>d</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mi>σ</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msup><mi>γ</mi><mo>*</mo></msup><mi>p</mi><mo>→</mo><mi>p</mi><msup><mi>π</mi><mn>0</mn></msup><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>ϕ</mi><mi>π</mi></msub></mrow></mfrac></mstyle></mrow></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex1.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle=\frac{d\sigma_{T}}{dt}+\epsilon\frac{d\sigma_{L}}{dt}+\epsilon%
\frac{d\sigma_{TT}}{dt}\cos 2\phi+\sqrt{2\epsilon(1+\epsilon)}\frac{d\sigma_{%
LT}}{dt}\cos\phi." display="inline"><mrow><mrow><mi/><mo>=</mo><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>σ</mi><mi>T</mi></msub></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac></mstyle><mo>+</mo><mrow><mi>ϵ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>σ</mi><mi>L</mi></msub></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac></mstyle></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mi>ϵ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>σ</mi><mrow><mi>T</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>T</mi></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac></mstyle><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mi>cos</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>ϕ</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><msqrt><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>ϵ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mi>ϵ</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></msqrt><mo>⁢</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>σ</mi><mrow><mi>L</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>T</mi></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac></mstyle><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mi>cos</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>ϕ</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

\noindent 
References~\cite{G-K-11,GL} obtain the following relations for unpolarized structure functions:

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E1.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle\frac{d\sigma_{L}}{dt}" display="inline"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>σ</mi><mi>L</mi></msub></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac></mstyle></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E1.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle=\frac{4\pi\alpha}{k^{\prime}}\frac{1}{Q^{4}}\left\{\left(1-\xi^{%
2}\right)\left|{\langle\tilde{H}\rangle}\right|^{2}-2\xi^{2}\text{Re}\left[{%
\langle\tilde{H}\rangle}^{*}{\langle\tilde{E}\rangle}\right]-\frac{t^{\prime}}%
{4m^{2}}\xi^{2}\left|{\langle\tilde{E}\rangle}\right|^{2}\right\}," display="inline"><mrow><mrow><mi/><mo>=</mo><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mrow><mn>4</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>π</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>α</mi></mrow><msup><mi>k</mi><mo>′</mo></msup></mfrac></mstyle><mo>⁢</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><msup><mi>Q</mi><mn>4</mn></msup></mfrac></mstyle><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>{</mo><mrow><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><msup><mi>ξ</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mrow><mo>|</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟨</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>H</mi><mo stretchy="false">~</mo></mover><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow><mo>|</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>ξ</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mtext>Re</mtext><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>[</mo><mrow><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟨</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>H</mi><mo stretchy="false">~</mo></mover><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow><mo>*</mo></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟨</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>E</mi><mo stretchy="false">~</mo></mover><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><msup><mi>t</mi><mo>′</mo></msup><mrow><mn>4</mn><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>m</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mfrac></mstyle><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>ξ</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mrow><mo>|</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟨</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>E</mi><mo stretchy="false">~</mo></mover><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow><mo>|</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mrow><mo>}</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E2.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle\frac{d\sigma_{T}}{dt}" display="inline"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>σ</mi><mi>T</mi></msub></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac></mstyle></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E2.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle=\frac{4\pi\alpha}{2k^{\prime}Q^{4}}\left[\left(1-\xi^{2}\right)%
\left|{\langle H_{T}\rangle}\right|^{2}-\frac{t^{\prime}}{8m^{2}}\left|{%
\langle\bar{E}_{T}\rangle}\right|^{2}\right]," display="inline"><mrow><mrow><mi/><mo>=</mo><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mrow><mn>4</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>π</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>α</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>k</mi><mo>′</mo></msup><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>Q</mi><mn>4</mn></msup></mrow></mfrac></mstyle><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>[</mo><mrow><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><msup><mi>ξ</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mrow><mo>|</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟨</mo><msub><mi>H</mi><mi>T</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow><mo>|</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><msup><mi>t</mi><mo>′</mo></msup><mrow><mn>8</mn><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>m</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mfrac></mstyle><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mrow><mo>|</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟨</mo><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>E</mi><mo stretchy="false">¯</mo></mover><mi>T</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow><mo>|</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mrow><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E3.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle\frac{d\sigma_{LT}}{dt}=\frac{4\pi\alpha}{\sqrt{2}k^{\prime}Q^{4}%
}\xi\sqrt{1-\xi^{2}}\frac{\sqrt{-t^{\prime}}}{2m}\text{ Re}\left[\langle H_{T}%
\rangle^{*}\langle\tilde{E}\rangle\right]," display="inline"><mrow><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>σ</mi><mrow><mi>L</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>T</mi></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac></mstyle><mo>=</mo><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mrow><mn>4</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>π</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>α</mi></mrow><mrow><msqrt><mn>2</mn></msqrt><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>k</mi><mo>′</mo></msup><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>Q</mi><mn>4</mn></msup></mrow></mfrac></mstyle><mo>⁢</mo><mi>ξ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msqrt><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><msup><mi>ξ</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></msqrt><mo>⁢</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><msqrt><mrow><mo>-</mo><msup><mi>t</mi><mo>′</mo></msup></mrow></msqrt><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>m</mi></mrow></mfrac></mstyle><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> Re</mtext><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>[</mo><mrow><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟨</mo><msub><mi>H</mi><mi>T</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow><mo>*</mo></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟨</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>E</mi><mo stretchy="false">~</mo></mover><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
\noindent 
Here $m$ is the mass of the proton, $t^\prime =t-t_{min}$, where $|t_{min}|$ is the minimum value of $|t|$ corresponding to $\theta_\pi =0$, $k^\prime(Q^2,x_B)$ is a phase space factor and  $\bar E_T = 2\widetilde H_T + E_T$.
The brackets $\langle  H_T \rangle$ and $\langle \bar E_T \rangle$ denote
the convolution of the elementary process 
$\gamma^*q\to q\pi^0$
with the GPDs $H_T$ and $\bar E_T$. We call them generalized form factors.



\begin{figure}[h]

\centerline{
\includegraphics[width=10cm]{pi0_eta_4_3_pptx.pdf}
}
\caption
{
(Color online) Structure functions $\sigma_T+\epsilon\sigma_L$ (black), $\sigma_{TT}$ (blue) and $\sigma_{LT}$ (red) as a function
of -$t$ for $\pi^0$ (left) and $\eta$(right) exclusive electroproduction for kinematic point ($Q^2=2.2$~GeV$^2$,$x_B$=0.28).
Data points: CLAS, preliminary. Curves: theoretical predictions produced with the GK handbag model.
}
\label{fig:structure}
\end{figure}



\section{Experimental data}
Cross section of the reaction $ep\rightarrow ep\pi^0$ measured by 
the CLAS collaboration at Jlab at
 1800 kinematic points in bins of $Q^2$, $x_B$, $t$ and $\phi$ were published in 
 Refs.
 \cite{clas1} and \cite{clas2}.
Structure functions $\sigma_U=\sigma_T+\epsilon\sigma_L$, $\sigma_{LT}$ and $\sigma_{TT}$ have been obtained. These functions were compared 
with the predictions of the GPD models \cite{G-K-11,GL}. CLAS confirmed that the measured unseparated cross sections are much larger than expected from 
leading-twist handbag calculations which are dominated by longitudinal photons. The same conclusion can be made in an almost model-independent way by noting that the structure functions $\sigma_U$ and $\left| \sigma_{TT}\right|$ are comparable to each other while $\left| \sigma_{LT}\right|$ is quite small (see Fig.\ref{fig:structure}).
Cross section and structure functions for $ep\to e \eta p$ were also obtained in parallel.
The comparison of the $\pi^0$ and preliminary $\eta$ structure functions is shown in Fig.~\ref{fig:structure}. 
$\sigma_U$ drops by a factor of 2.5 for $\eta$ in comparison with $\pi^0$ and
$\sigma_{TT}$ drops by a factor of 10.
The GK GPD model \cite{G-K-11}  (curves)  follows the experimental data.
The inclusion of $\eta$ data into consideration strengthens 
the statement about the transversity GPD dominance in the pseudoscalar electroproduction process.





\section{Generalized Form Factors}
The squared magnitudes of the 
generalized form factors
$\left|{\langle H_T \rangle}\right|^2$ and 
$\left|{\langle \bar{E}_T \rangle}\right|^2$  
may be directly extracted from the experimental data (see Eqs. \ref{ST} and \ref{STT} ) in the framework of GPD models.

prevtext:
\noindent 
Here $m$ is the mass of the proton, $t^\prime =t-t_{min}$, where $|t_{min}|$ is the minimum value of $|t|$ corresponding to $\theta_\pi =0$, $k^\prime(Q^2,x_B)$ is a phase space factor and  $\bar E_T = 2\widetilde H_T + E_T$.
The brackets $\langle  H_T \rangle$ and $\langle \bar E_T \rangle$ denote
the convolution of the elementary process 
$\gamma^*q\to q\pi^0$
with the GPDs $H_T$ and $\bar E_T$. We call them generalized form factors.

of -$t$ for $\pi^0$ (left) and $\eta$(right) exclusive electroproduction for kinematic point ($Q^2=2.2$~GeV$^2$,$x_B$=0.28).
Data points: CLAS, preliminary. Curves: theoretical predictions produced with the GK handbag model.
}
\label{fig:structure}
\end{figure}



\section{Experimental data}
Cross section of the reaction $ep\rightarrow ep\pi^0$ measured by 
the CLAS collaboration at Jlab at
 1800 kinematic points in bins of $Q^2$, $x_B$, $t$ and $\phi$ were published in 
 Refs.
 \cite{clas1} and \cite{clas2}.
Structure functions $\sigma_U=\sigma_T+\epsilon\sigma_L$, $\sigma_{LT}$ and $\sigma_{TT}$ have been obtained. These functions were compared 
with the predictions of the GPD models \cite{G-K-11,GL}. CLAS confirmed that the measured unseparated cross sections are much larger than expected from 
leading-twist handbag calculations which are dominated by longitudinal photons. The same conclusion can be made in an almost model-independent way by noting that the structure functions $\sigma_U$ and $\left| \sigma_{TT}\right|$ are comparable to each other while $\left| \sigma_{LT}\right|$ is quite small (see Fig.\ref{fig:structure}).
Cross section and structure functions for $ep\to e \eta p$ were also obtained in parallel.
The comparison of the $\pi^0$ and preliminary $\eta$ structure functions is shown in Fig.~\ref{fig:structure}.

$\sigma_{TT}$ drops by a factor of 10.

The inclusion of $\eta$ data into consideration strengthens

\section{Generalized Form Factors}
The squared magnitudes of the 
generalized form factors
$\left|{\langle H_T \rangle}\right|^2$ and 
$\left|{\langle \bar{E}_T \rangle}\right|^2$  
may be directly extracted from the experimental data (see Eqs. \ref{ST} and \ref{STT} ) in the framework of GPD models.
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E5X.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle\left|{\langle\bar{E}_{T}\rangle}^{\pi,\eta}\right|^{2}" display="inline"><msup><mrow><mo>|</mo><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟨</mo><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>E</mi><mo stretchy="false">¯</mo></mover><mi>T</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>π</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>η</mi></mrow></msup><mo>|</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E5X.m3" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle=\frac{k^{\prime}Q^{4}}{4\pi\alpha}\frac{16m^{2}}{t^{\prime}}%
\frac{d\sigma^{\pi,\eta}_{TT}}{dt}" display="inline"><mrow><mi/><mo>=</mo><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mrow><msup><mi>k</mi><mo>′</mo></msup><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>Q</mi><mn>4</mn></msup></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>π</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>α</mi></mrow></mfrac></mstyle><mo>⁢</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mrow><mn>16</mn><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>m</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><msup><mi>t</mi><mo>′</mo></msup></mfrac></mstyle><mo>⁢</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>σ</mi><mrow><mi>T</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>T</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>π</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>η</mi></mrow></msubsup></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac></mstyle></mrow></mrow></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E5Xa.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle\left|{\langle H_{T}\rangle}^{\pi,\eta}\right|^{2}" display="inline"><msup><mrow><mo>|</mo><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟨</mo><msub><mi>H</mi><mi>T</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>π</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>η</mi></mrow></msup><mo>|</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E5Xa.m3" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle=\frac{2k^{\prime}Q^{4}}{4\pi\alpha}\frac{1}{1-\xi^{2}}\left[%
\frac{d\sigma^{\pi,\eta}_{T}}{dt}+\frac{d\sigma^{\pi,\eta}_{TT}}{dt}\right]." display="inline"><mrow><mrow><mi/><mo>=</mo><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>k</mi><mo>′</mo></msup><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>Q</mi><mn>4</mn></msup></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>π</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>α</mi></mrow></mfrac></mstyle><mo>⁢</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><msup><mi>ξ</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mfrac></mstyle><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>[</mo><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>σ</mi><mi>T</mi><mrow><mi>π</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>η</mi></mrow></msubsup></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac></mstyle><mo>+</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>σ</mi><mrow><mi>T</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>T</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>π</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>η</mi></mrow></msubsup></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac></mstyle></mrow><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
\noindent
The $q$ and $\bar q$ GPDs contribute in the quark combinations $F^q_i-F^{\bar q}_i$. 
Hence there is no contribution from the strange quarks if we assume that
$F^s_i\simeq F^{\bar s}_i$. 
For flavor decomposition we have to take into account the decay constants $f_\pi$ and $f_\eta$, the chiral  condensate
constants $\mu_{\pi^0}=$2.57~GeV, $\mu_1=$0.958~GeV and $\mu_8$=2.32~GeV, and the contribution from singlet and octet $\eta$ states.\cite{G-K-11}
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E6X.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle F^{\pi}_{i}" display="inline"><msubsup><mi>F</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>π</mi></msubsup></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E6X.m3" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}[e_{u}F^{u}_{i}-e_{d}F^{d}_{i}]" display="inline"><mrow><mi/><mo>=</mo><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><msqrt><mn>2</mn></msqrt></mfrac></mstyle><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>e</mi><mi>u</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>F</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>u</mi></msubsup></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><msub><mi>e</mi><mi>d</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>F</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>d</mi></msubsup></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E6Xa.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle F^{\eta}_{i}" display="inline"><msubsup><mi>F</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>η</mi></msubsup></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E6Xa.m3" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle=\frac{1}{\sqrt{6}}[e_{u}F^{u}_{i}+e_{d}F^{d}_{i}-2e_{s}F^{s}_{i}]" display="inline"><mrow><mi/><mo>=</mo><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><msqrt><mn>6</mn></msqrt></mfrac></mstyle><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>e</mi><mi>u</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>F</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>u</mi></msubsup></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><msub><mi>e</mi><mi>d</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>F</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>d</mi></msubsup></mrow></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>e</mi><mi>s</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>F</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>s</mi></msubsup></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext:
\noindent
where the mixing angles are:
$\theta_8=-21.2^o$ and $\theta_1=-9.2^o$.
The octet and singlet wave functions are very similar and the decay constants are close as well
$f_8=1.26f_\pi$ and 
$f_1=1.17f_\pi$.
The overall factor for the $\eta$ meson is 
$k_\eta=0.863$.
Using $e_u=\frac{2}{3}$ and $e_d=-\frac{1}{3}$ we will end up with
equations
prevtext:
\noindent
The $q$ and $\bar q$ GPDs contribute in the quark combinations $F^q_i-F^{\bar q}_i$. 
Hence there is no contribution from the strange quarks if we assume that
$F^s_i\simeq F^{\bar s}_i$. 
For flavor decomposition we have to take into account the decay constants $f_\pi$ and $f_\eta$, the chiral  condensate
constants $\mu_{\pi^0}=$2.57~GeV, $\mu_1=$0.958~GeV and $\mu_8$=2.32~GeV, and the contribution from singlet and octet $\eta$ states.\cite{G-K-11}

nexttext:
\noindent
\noindent
Experimentally we have  access only to the $\left|\left<F_i^\pi\right>\right|^2$ and $\left|\left<F_i^\eta\right>\right|^2$
(see Eq.~\ref{ET_HT}).
The final equation for the $\left<H_T\right>$ convolution reads
prevtext:
\noindent
where the mixing angles are:
$\theta_8=-21.2^o$ and $\theta_1=-9.2^o$.
The octet and singlet wave functions are very similar and the decay constants are close as well
$f_8=1.26f_\pi$ and 
$f_1=1.17f_\pi$.
The overall factor for the $\eta$ meson is 
$k_\eta=0.863$.
Using $e_u=\frac{2}{3}$ and $e_d=-\frac{1}{3}$ we will end up with
equations
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E8X.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle F^{\pi}_{i}" display="inline"><msubsup><mi>F</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>π</mi></msubsup></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E8X.m3" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle=\frac{1}{3\sqrt{2}}[2F^{u}_{i}+F^{d}_{i}]" display="inline"><mrow><mi/><mo>=</mo><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>⁢</mo><msqrt><mn>2</mn></msqrt></mrow></mfrac></mstyle><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>F</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>u</mi></msubsup></mrow><mo>+</mo><msubsup><mi>F</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>d</mi></msubsup></mrow><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E8Xa.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle{k_{\eta}}{F^{\eta}_{i}}" display="inline"><mrow><msub><mi>k</mi><mi>η</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>F</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>η</mi></msubsup></mrow></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E8Xa.m3" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle=\frac{1}{3\sqrt{6}}[2F^{u}_{i}-F^{d}_{i}]." display="inline"><mrow><mrow><mi/><mo>=</mo><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>⁢</mo><msqrt><mn>6</mn></msqrt></mrow></mfrac></mstyle><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>F</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>u</mi></msubsup></mrow><mo>-</mo><msubsup><mi>F</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>d</mi></msubsup></mrow><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
\noindent
and simular equations for ${\langle \bar{E}_T \rangle}$.
\begin{figure}[h]
\vspace*{-10 mm}
\centerline{
\includegraphics[width=12cm]{ud_3_pptx.pdf}
}
\vspace*{-10 mm}
\caption
{
(Color online) Preliminary. 
Top: Extracted ${\langle H_T \rangle}^u$ (red) and ${\langle H_T \rangle}^d$ (blue);
Bottom: ${\langle \bar{E}_T \rangle}^u$ (red) and ${\langle \bar{E}_T \rangle}^d$ (blue),
as a function of -$t$ for $Q^2=2.2~GeV^2$  and $x_B$=0.27.
}
\label{fig:ud_3}
\end{figure}
\noindent
The solution of these equations will lead to the flavor decomposition of the transversity GPDs 
${\langle H_T \rangle}^u$ and  ${\langle H_T \rangle}^d$ as well as  ${\langle \bar{E}_T \rangle}^u$ and ${\langle \bar{E}_T \rangle}^d$.
However the  convolution integrals have real and imaginary parts. So it is impossible to  solve these equations unambiguously with only two equations in hands.
As a guidance  we can estimate the form factors if we suppose that the
relative phase $\Delta\phi$ between ${\langle H_T \rangle}^u$ and ${\langle H_T \rangle}^d$ equals 0 or 180 degrees. 
Ignoring an overall phase, the form factors are then real and we arbitrarily choose the solution with 
  ${\langle H_T \rangle}^u$ and  ${\langle \bar{E}_T \rangle}^u$ positive.
Fig.~\ref{fig:ud_3}  presents 
${\langle H_T \rangle}^u$, ${\langle H_T \rangle}^d$, ${\langle \bar{E}_T \rangle}^u$ and ${\langle \bar{E}_T \rangle}^d$
for one kinematic point $(Q^2=2.2~GeV^2,x_B=0.27)$ calculated in this assumption. 
Note the different signs of ${\langle H_T \rangle}^u$ and  ${\langle H_T \rangle}^d$ convolutions and the same sign
of ${\langle \bar{E}_T \rangle}^u$ and ${\langle \bar{E}_T \rangle}^d$.



\section{Conclusion}
Differential cross sections of exclusive $\pi^0$ and $\eta$ electroproduction have been obtained in the few-GeV region at more than 1800 kinematic points in  bins of $Q^2, x_B$, $t$ and $\phi_\pi$. 
Virtual photon structure functions  
$\sigma_U$, $\sigma_{TT}$ and $d\sigma_{LT}$ have been obtained. It is found that $\sigma_U$ and $\sigma_{TT}$ are comparable in magnitude with each other, while $\sigma_{LT}$ is very much smaller than either. 
Generalized form factors of the transversity GPDs ${\langle H_T \rangle}^{\pi,\eta}$ and ${\langle \bar{E}_T \rangle}^{\pi,\eta}$ were directly extracted from the experimental observables
for the first time. It was found that the GPD $\bar E_T$ dominates in  pseudoscalar meson production.
The combined $\pi^0$ and $\eta$ data opens the way for the flavor decomposition of the transversity GPDs. 
Within some simplifying assumptions, the  decomposition has been  demonstrated for the first time.

\noindent
Experimentally we have  access only to the $\left|\left<F_i^\pi\right>\right|^2$ and $\left|\left<F_i^\eta\right>\right|^2$
(see Eq.~\ref{ET_HT}).
The final equation for the $\left<H_T\right>$ convolution reads
